title: 111_hr1815
content:
The Act titled "Consumer Product Safety Solutions Act of 2009" mandates lead limits and third-party testing requirements for consumer products. The Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act of 2008, amended in the Consumer Product Safety Solutions Act of 2009, sets lead content limits for children's products at 600 parts per million starting February 10, 2009, and 300 parts per million starting 2 years after the enactment date. The amendments made by the Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act of 2008, as amended in the Consumer Product Safety Solutions Act of 2009, apply to all children's products regardless of the date of manufacture. The effective date of these amendments is August 15, 2008. SEC. 3. PROSPECTIVE APPLICATION OF PHTHALATES PROHIBITION.

The phthalates prohibition under the Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act of 2008 applies to children's products manufactured after February 10, 2009, and to all children's products after February 9, 2010, regardless of the manufacture date.

SEC. 4. CLARIFICATION OF TESTING METHODOLOGIES. The Consumer Product Safety Commission must establish testing methodologies for compliance with the Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act within 180 days of enactment. Amendments to the Consumer Product Safety Act specify effective dates for conformity certification. Temporary compliance rules apply until the testing methodologies rule is issued. Children's products tested for conformity with the requirements of the Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act of 2008 and certified under the Consumer Product Safety Act will be considered compliant if tested in good faith and certified based on the results of testing. The Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act of 2008 is amended to exclude certain materials from lead content limits, ensuring that products intended for children will not absorb excessive amounts of lead into the human body. SEC. 6. WAIVER OF THIRD PARTY TESTING REQUIREMENT FOR CERTAIN COMPONENT PARTS. Section 14(g) of the Consumer Product Safety Act is amended to exempt manufacturers or private labelers of children's products from testing and certifying for lead and phthalate content if each component has already been tested for compliance with relevant regulations. The manufacturer or private labeler of each component must certify compliance with lead and phthalate limits set by the Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act of 2008. SEC. 7 amends the Consumer Product Safety Act to allow the Commission to exempt or modify tracking label requirements if they are deemed burdensome or cost prohibitive. SEC. 8 provides general application and exemptive authority. Section 3 of the Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act of 2008 is amended to allow the Commission to extend or delay effective dates for specific manufacturers, distributors, or retailers if it promotes public safety. The Commission also has the authority to exempt certain entities from provisions of the Act. The Commission can delay provisions of the Act for manufacturers, distributors, or retailers if it promotes public safety and is in the public interest. SEC. 9. COMPLIANCE GUIDANCE FOR SMALL BUSINESSES. The Consumer Product Safety Commission will develop a compliance guide for small businesses to help them understand the requirements of the Consumer Product Safety Act and other Acts enforced by the Commission. The guide will assist businesses in determining if the Acts apply to them, their role (distributor, manufacturer, etc.), and the specific rules and regulations that apply to their business. The Consumer Product Safety Commission will develop a compliance guide for small businesses to help them understand and comply with statutory requirements. The guide will provide guidance on how to comply with applicable rules, standards, regulations, and requirements, including actions to take and how to determine compliance. Additionally, it may include contact information for compliance support.
